If the CI included zero, the median delta value was defined as statistically non-significant. To test differences in hemodynamics between discordant and concordant voxels, we used paired, two-sided t-tests on the median subject values; to test for baseline differences, we used independent-sample permutation tests on the median voxel values. External, high-resolution maps were downsampled to 2mm MNI standard space before analyses were conducted.

ack.p: CP has been funded by the Deutsche Forschungsgemeinschaft (DFG, German Research Foundation, ID 395030489), and VR has been supported by the European Research Council (ERC) under the European Union’s Horizon 2020 research and innovation program (ERC Starting Grant, ID 759659).

sec.title: Data and Code Availability
sec.p: All raw and processed data are available in the online repository of OpenNeuro (Epp et al., 2023) (https://openneuro.org/datasets/ds004873). The scripts, Python Jupyter notebooks, docker container for quantitative parameter map analyses, and configuration files for replication of all analyses and figures are available on GitHub (https://github.com/NeuroenergeticsLab/two_modes_of_hemodynamics).

caption.title: Study design, quantitative fMRI, and the hemodynamic response model of BOLD fMRI.
caption.p: A| We performed BOLD- and quantitative fMRI on healthy subjects performing four different conditions within the same imaging session: calculation task (CALC), autobiographical memory task (MEM), active control baseline (CTRL), and uncontrolled resting-state baseline (REST). B| During each imaging session, we acquired BOLD fMRI data with a 30-sec block design, together with multiparametric, quantitative BOLD (mqBOLD) data while conditions were presented in pseudo-randomized order: T2* mapping to measure both reversible and irreversible dephasing; pseudo-continuous arterial spin labeling (pCASL) to measure CBF during each condition; T2 mapping to once measure irreversible dephasing due to tissue properties; dynamic susceptibility contrast (DSC) MRI using a contrast agent to measure CBV during CTRL, at the end of the session. C| Quantitative fMRI delivers voxelwise CMRO2 by integrating T2, T2*, CBV, and CBF parameters via Fick’s principle (see Methods section for detailed equations). Brain slices of subject-average parameter maps and boxplots illustrating average GM values (line, median; box limits, upper and lower quartiles; individual dots, subject average per condition). The reversible transverse relaxation rate (R2’) reflects a voxel’s overall deoxyhemoglobin (dHb) content. The OEF is proportional to R2’/CBV. Voxel-wise CMRO2 is then calculated as the product of OEF, CBF, and the arterial oxygen content of the blood (CaO2) as derived from individual measures of oxygen saturation and hematocrit. D| The canonical, hemodynamic response model of the BOLD signal: Increased neuronal activity leads to higher oxygen metabolism (CMRO2), decreasing oxygenation levels and increased dHb content in venous blood. Simultaneously, neurovascular coupling mechanisms cause an increase in CBV and CBF. This hemodynamic response counteracts the effects of oxygen metabolism, leading to a total decrease in dHb content. In BOLD-fMRI, the net fluctuation of dHb levels is dynamically measured with T2*-weighted (T2*w) echo planar imaging (EPI). ΔBOLD during any task condition is calculated by subtracting task (T) from baseline (B) T2*w data. Based on this canonical model, positive ΔBOLD [%] is commonly interpreted as increased neuronal activity.

caption.title: Negative BOLD signal changes do not necessarily indicate a reduction in oxygen metabolism.
caption.p: A| Statistical results of the PLS group analysis in standard MNI space, comparing CALC and CTRL, for both BOLD and quantitative fMRI parameter maps. Maps projected on the brain surface show non-thresholded bootstrap ratios (BSR, akin to z-values) of the first latent variable, which was significant in each analysis, i.e., for BOLD, CBF, and CMRO2 respectively (permutation tests, p < .001). Red voxels indicate higher values during CALC than during CTRL, while blue voxels represent the opposite contrast. Axial slices display significant brain clusters, thresholded at BSR ±2 (akin to p < .05, cluster size > 30 voxels) for the BOLD, CBF, and CMRO2 signals. B| Histograms depict group-average median voxel distributions of ΔBOLD, ΔCBF, and ΔCMRO2 (CALC minus CTRL) within the binarized CALC-positive and CALC-negative group masks (shown as surface plot). C| Subject distribution of ΔBOLD, ΔCBF, and ΔCMRO2 in native space. Dots represent subject values, calculated as the median across voxels within individual BOLD masks of significant positive (orange) and negative (blue) ΔBOLD. Paired samples, two-sided t-tests, ** p < .001. Gray lines connect values obtained from individual subjects, and red lines indicate subjects where the sign of ΔCBF or ΔCMRO2 deviates from the BOLD-indicated direction. D| Regional clusters (designated by numbers) of positive and negative ΔBOLD (PLS group results, thresholded at BSR > ±3) and associated bar plots showing ΔBOLD and ΔCMRO2. Please note the different axes for ΔBOLD versus ΔCMRO2. Bars indicate ΔBOLD[%] and ΔCMRO2[%] median across voxels, error bars 95% CI, 2000 bootstraps, and dots represent subject values. Any signal increase or decrease where error bars cross the zero line is considered non-significant; an asterisk denotes p < 0.05. Clusters are located in different functional networks, as depicted on the brain surface and in axial slices (Thomas Yeo et al., 2011): visual (VIS); dorsal attention (DAN); frontoparietal (FPN); ventral attention (VAN); somatomotor (SMN); default mode (DMN) network.

caption.title: Dependence of BOLD responses on changes in CBF and CMRO2.
caption.p: A| Visualization of the Davis model. Predicted BOLD responses (ΔBOLD[%]) are depicted as colored contour lines across ΔCBF[%] and ΔCMRO2[%]. The model illustrates that, for a given ΔCMRO2[%], the sign and amplitude of the BOLD response depend on the amplitudes of ΔCBF[%]. The canonical hemodynamic response model requires that ΔCBF surpasses ΔCMRO2, resulting in a positive ΔBOLD and vice versa for negative BOLD signal changes. However, the Davis model also predicts a range of BOLD responses with discordant signs compared to the change in underlying metabolic activity (violet shading). B| Empirical data from BOLD- and quantitative fMRI for all cortical voxels. ΔCMRO2 was calculated from semi-quantitative data (see Methods), median across all subjects per voxel, with colors indicating ΔBOLD[%]. Our experimental data replicate the slope and range of values as predicted by the Davis model, particularly demonstrating a substantial number of voxels with ΔBOLD opposing ΔCMRO2. C| Voxels with significantly positive (top) and negative (bottom) BOLD responses from (B) are plotted separately here. Voxels with ΔBOLD concordant to ΔCMRO2 are depicted on a pale (yellow/turquoise) background, while voxels with discordant ΔBOLD are shown on a violet background. The pie plots summarize the ratio of discordant to concordant voxels. In the lower panel, the pie plot with black contours summarizes the ratio of discordant voxels within only the DMN. Axial slices illustrate the spatial distribution of significantly concordant and discordant BOLD voxels, with black contours indicating the DMN. The stacked bars in the right center depict the amplitude distribution of discordant and concordant voxels across BOLD amplitude quartiles. It is noteworthy that discordant voxels show neither spatial nor amplitude preference. D| The boxplots summarize ΔCMRO2[%] and ΔCBF[%] across all voxels with either concordant or discordant ΔBOLD[%]; line, median; box limits, upper and lower quartiles. Please note that discordant and concordant voxels feature a similar ΔBOLD amplitude distribution despite indicating opposite metabolic responses.

caption.title: Concordant or discordant BOLD signal responses depend on baseline OEF.
caption.p: A| Conjunction voxels (green outlines) – showing positive and negative BOLD signal changes during either CALC or MEM – were sorted according to their response type. The pie chart summarizes the consistency of response types across voxels: 35% of all conjunction voxels showed concordant responses (same sign of ΔBOLD and ΔCMRO2) during both MEM and CALC conditions (‘concordant only’). 18% of all conjunction voxels showed discordant responses in both conditions (‘discordant only’). 48% of the conjunction voxels (‘mixed’ voxels) showed concordant responses in one condition but discordant responses in the other. B| Spatial distribution is depicted on brain slices using consistent color overlays: ‘Concordant only’ and ‘mixed’ voxels mainly cluster in regions of the DMN, while ‘discordant only’ voxels occur in the medial part of the VAN. The boxplots illustrate subject-median parameter values separately for ‘concordant only,’ ‘mixed,’ and ‘discordant only’ voxels. While the range of ΔBOLD is similar across the three groups, ΔCBF and ΔCMRO2 vary strongly as expressed by their n-ratios. Asterisks indicate significant differences from zero, tested via independent t-tests corrected for multiple comparisons. C| The three voxel groups exhibit significantly different OEF during CTRL baseline, with ‘concordant only’ voxels having significantly higher OEF and ‘discordant only’ voxels having significantly lower OEF than ‘mixed’ voxels. ** p < 0.001, independent sample permutation test on the median values, conducted for ‘mixed’ versus the two other voxel types, 2000 permutations.

caption.title: Two types of hemodynamic responses via changes in CBF or OEF.
caption.p: A| Across all task conditions, 21% of all GM voxels showed discordant, 32% showed concordant responses, and 48% were not significantly involved in any task. Regression plots: During baseline, CMRO2 and CBF show a medium correlation (Pearson’s r > 0.32, p < .001), CMRO2 and OEF are highly correlated (r > 0.7, p < .001), and CMRO2 and CBV show a weak negative correlation (r < -0.1, p < 0.001) across all groups of voxels. B| Across subjects, discordant (disc.) voxels, on average, show significantly lower CBF (-3.4%), OEF (-5.7%), and higher CBV (2.1%) than concordant (conc.) voxels (paired-samples, two-sided t-test, p < .001). Boxplots: line, median; box limits, upper and lower quartiles; gray line, median of remaining GM voxels. C| Marginally, but significantly lower baseline susceptibility (QSM) and higher venous density in discordant vs. concordant voxels, revealed by two external datasets (Huck et al., 2019; Lüsebrink et al., 2021). Boxplots: line, median; box limits, upper and lower quartiles; gray line, median of remaining GM voxels. ** p < .001, independent samples permutation test on the median values, conducted for discordant versus concordant voxels, 2000 permutations. D| Correlation of ΔCMRO2[%] with either ΔCBF[%], ΔOEF[%], or ΔCBV[%] across all task contrasts (CALC or MEM vs. CTRL), separately for concordant (pale) and discordant (dark violet) voxels. ΔCMRO2 and ΔCBF showed a strong positive correlation across concordant voxels (r = .87, p < 0.001) and a moderate correlation across discordant voxels (r = .48, p < .001). In contrast, ΔCMRO2 and ΔOEF showed a moderate, positive correlation across discordant voxels (r = .60, p < .001) and a weak, negative correlation across concordant voxels (r = -.41, p < .001). ΔCBV could only be evaluated for a subset of 10 subjects and only across the CALC vs. CTRL contrast, see Methods. ΔCMRO2 and ΔCBV across this subset showed a weak correlation around zero across concordant voxels (r = -.07) and a moderate, negative correlation across discordant voxels (r = - .46, p < 0.001).

caption.title: Whole-brain (GM) parameter values, mean ± SD across subjects and conditions.

caption.p: Mean BOLD signal change and parameter values of the mqBOLD approach across subjects (standard deviation) within individual BOLD-fMRI masks, separately for positive and negative BOLD responses.

fn.p: Note. Quantitative values (black font) of CBF, CMRO2, and OEF are displayed both at baseline and as absolute delta values (task minus baseline), along with percent change values (colored) for each contrast. Values reflect data as displayed in Fig. 2C, with CMRO2 values in CALC being corrected for CBV increases, see Methods.
p < .001, based on paired, two-sided t-tests, df = 39 for CALC vs. CTRL contrasts, df = 29 for CALC vs. REST and MEM vs. CTRL contrasts.
